awd_titl_txt: CPS: Medium: Collaborative Research: Collective Intelligence for Proactive Autonomous Driving (CI-PAD)
awd_abstract_narration:
The aim of this project is to develop real-time situational awareness that is shared via vehicle-to-vehicle (V2V) and vehicle-to-network (V2X). The approach is to combine the perception of sensors with interpretation of their situation to enable safer decisions, and take into account the limitations of the communication between vehicles and infrastructure. A highway system that supports autonomous and self-driven vehicles will include infrastructure sensors and onboard vehicle sensors, with massive connectivity among them and distributed intelligence across the entire transportation network. The resulting collective intelligence is one where autonomous vehicles serve as mobile sensors that augment one another along with fixed infrastructure sensors, to construct a real-time picture of traffic. This real-time picture is used to develop proactive driving actions that optimize traffic flow and minimize accident risk. The broader impacts include focused mentoring of undergraduate students who are interested in careers that require graduate training, to broaden participation in the fields of computing and engineering.

The researchers organize an interdisciplinary project in signal processing and machine learning, control and optimization, communication and network science. The collective intelligence framework for proactive driving includes the following modules: 1) Scene Construction, consisting of signal processing and machine learning for constructing a representation of the driving environment from multi-modal multi-view sensors; 2) Situational Interpretation, consisting of driving environment dynamic analysis at progressive levels; 3) Decision Making, consisting of optimization and control to support proactive driving for safety and optimized flow; and 4) A Failsafe Network, consisting of communication and network science that supports optimized traffic flow under nominal conditions of sensing and communication, and moderated flow under conditions of compromised sensing and communication.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

por.por_cntn:
The context and major goal of this project is to develop real-time awareness of vehicles in the transportation network utilized in our daily life. This collective intelligence of automobiles is shared by vehicle-to-vehicle (V2V) and vehicle-to-network (V2X) communication links. The vision is to combine roadside and car sensor signals to take safe decisions based on artificial intelligence (AI) and real-time traffic depiction, while accounting for the challenges facing V2V and V2X communications.

The outcomes of our collective intelligence framework for proactive driving is pursued in four thrusts.

O1) Scene construction enabled by multi-modal multi-view sensors leveraging state-of-the-art  signal processing and machine learning modules to depict the driving state and traffic landscape;

O2) Situational interpretation of dynamic the dynamic driving environment at progressive levels;

O3) Decision making to support proactive driving for safety and optimized flow; and

O4) A failsafe network, consisting of communication and network science that supports optimized traffic flow under nominal conditions of sensing and communication, along with moderated flow under conditions of compromised sensing and communication.

Major research outcomes with intellectual merits have included (i) Priority-based autonomous intersection management for connected automated vehicles;  (ii) hierarchical traffic flow prediction based on spatio-temporal graph convolutional networks; (iii) Integrated distributed wireless sensing with over-the-air federated learning; iv) Blind online IoV management; and (v) Robust and active meta-learning over IoV graphs.

 

Major educational/training outcomes in this project, with broader impacts to education and training the next cadre of engineers with AI-driven expertise for transportation systems, have included:

E1) Seven (7) Ph.D. and three (3) M.Sc. Theses were supervised; along with four (5) postdoctoral researchers that were trained on themes related to data science and network science with application to Internet of Things (IoT) and Internet of Vehicles (IoV). Out of these 15 individuals, 7 joined Industry groups (including 3M, Google, Apple, Microsoft, Samsung, Amazon), and 6 joined academic institutions (U. of Georgia, Michigan State U., Washington State U., Hong Kong U. of Science and Technology, and U. of Wisconsin) as assistant professors, or, as postdoctoral researchers (ETH, U. of Texas, Austin).    

E2) Monthly reading group meetings on advances related to online convex optimization and machine learning for big data analytics with applications to monitoring and resource allocation for IoV, IoT, communication, sensing and power grids with renewables and electric vehicles. The PI also integrated research with educational modules in Senior Design of Undergraduate Projects, the latest dealing with large-learning models and ChatGPT.

Developing scalable and robust learning approaches for large-scale IoVs provided the postdocs and graduate students working on this project with deep understanding of graph theory, Gaussian Processes, crowdsourcing approaches, the value of integrating sensing and communication over IoVs, parallel, incremental, active and decentralized learning algorithms, topology identification, interpolation and extrapolation principles, as well as the fundamentals of statistical inference and Bayesian optimization theory. They further gained hands-on experience with practical models, real data processing, and simulations of the entire protocol stack.

As far as dissemination, the research outcomes have reached communities of interest through research publications, conference and workshop presentations (more than 60 over the last 3 years). In addition, the PI delivered keynote addresses, plenaries, tutorials, and invited talks at academic institutions, as well as industrial research labs (more than 50 over the last 3 years).

In most of these addresses, the PI presented advances of learning approaches for large-scale graphs with applications to monitoring and optimizing the design of wireless communication and computing networks, as well as transportation and power grid networks. His talks further covered broader impact themes on machine learning and related statistical tools for network science. 

Besides transportation networks, other disciplines have been impacted through the analytical, algorithmic, and computational models, tools, and outcomes of this project, go well beyond the envisioned application context of V2V and V2I IoV networks. These broader disciplines include the  fields of optimization, stochastic processes, control systems, machine learning, and statistical signal processing. Insights gained from this project’s large-scale network analytics context, will also transfer technology to a gamut of other exciting problem domains, including IoTs, communication and social networks, computational biology, neuroscience, economy, as well as the social sciences. In addition to markedly influencing future sensing and resource allocation modules, insights gained from this project's learning and inference approaches will also cross-fertilize benefits to a gamut of additional disciplines, including smart grids, smart cities, and self-driving vehicles.

Networks play a fundamental role not only in science and economy, but also in our daily life. At a broader scale, the developed technologies will promote societal embracing of the emergent AI-guided and autonomous driving technologies. 


Last Modified: 03/08/2024
Modified by: Georgios B Giannakis
